citances.sentence: When reference is made in s 33C(1)(c) to a " substantial common issue of law or fact ", the term " substantial " does not indicate that which is " large " or " of special significance " or would " have a major impact on the ... litigation " but, rather, is directed to issues which are " real or of substance ": Wong v Silkfield Pty Ltd , supra, at [28] per Gleeson CJ, McHugh, Gummow, Kirby and Callinan JJ. See also: Wotton v Queensland [2009] FCA 758 at [35] [2009] FCA 758 ; , 109 ALD 534 at 543 to 544. Even though there may be factual variations in claims advanced, it does not follow that s 33C(1)(c) is not satisfied: Green v Barzen Pty Ltd (formerly Dukes Financial Services Pty Ltd) [2008] FCA 920 at [13] . Finkelstein J there further observed that it " will be enough if there is at least a common nucleus of operative facts or legal issues. It will also suffice if what is alleged in substance amounts to a common course of conduct directed toward a particular group ...".
